channel.title: Jira
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [ERLLM-144] er-dob-extractor Address Issues / Improve Recall
item.description:
https://www.notion.so/xapien/er-dob-extractor-evaluation-december-2025-1591edcf1daa807b8437d3e27ab91501

Running content tests (n=120) made it apparent that the service misses lots of dates of birth. This is because it appears the way dates appear in text is often very different to what we expect.

The service does not seem to struggle with false positives. So when it gives us something, that something appears (from my testing) to be always correct.

Some linked tickets from Harrison

  • Have seen false positives in the wild causing issues - but they are rare.
    e.g. known hard underlink caused by incorrect DoB extraction https://digital-insight.atlassian.net/browse/ERAC-145
  • Also a known issue in our DoB handling logic which is overly sensitive to "VeryGood" quality dates https://digital-insight.atlassian.net/browse/ERAC-320
  • And the mistakesAllowed logic isn't perfect https://digital-insight.atlassian.net/browse/ERAC-325

New note from Jonah (19/12/2024)

Current System

Input -> Current Output of DOB service
Robert Arthur Kardashian (born 01/02/2000) -> somePointIn(2000-01-02/2000-01-02)
Robert Arthur Kardashian (born 02/01/2000) -> somePointIn(2000-02-01/2000-02-01)

This seems wrong. We don’t know if it is DD/MM/YYYY or MM/DD/YYYY. Whoever picks up this ticket, you need to figure out from the right person (probably Joseph) what the desired behaviour is here.

item.title: [ERLLM-142] er-dre-extractor Investigate Consistency Issues
item.description:
https://www.notion.so/xapien/er-dre-extractor-3-5-4o-mini-swapover-1591edcf1daa80a484f9fa5371bcf533

It appears that currently the dre extraction service is quite inconsistent. We see lots of differences between runs. We should determine if this is important, and if it is look at coming up with fixes for it.

→ Make a second call to the model asking to confirm this is all the dres

→ Make multiple calls in parallel and aggregate results

→ limit the document size that goes in, if it is determined that it is long documents resulting in us missing some dres

item.title: [ERLLM-141] er-aka-extractor Anchor Terms Handling
item.description:
The way we handle anchor terms in er-aka-extractor is a bit weird.

If an anchor term appears in the text, we dump all anchor terms into a user prompt to look for AKAs.

This should instead probably only pass the AKA which was hit. Then we can also log which aka it was that was hit more cleanly.

https://github.com/Digital-Insight-Technologies-Ltd/er-aka-extractor/blob/main/er_aka_extractor/src/prompt_building_and_parsing.py#L28

item.title: [ERLLM-140] er-detailed-summary-generator Redo Prompting
item.description:
Some things to look at:

  • often the response starts with “the article states that …”. Do we want this?
  • should probably split to system and user prompt
  • it will waffle for people. For the input
"David schwimmer is the CEO of LSEG."

We get the output 

"david schwimmer is the ceo of lseg (london stock exchange group). the article highlights his leadership role within the organization, indicating that he is at the helm of one of the world's leading financial market infrastructure and data providers. as ceo, schwimmer is likely responsible for overseeing the strategic direction and operational management of lseg, which plays a crucial role in facilitating global financial markets. his position suggests that he is involved in key decision-making processes that impact the company's performance and its contributions to the financial industry."

This uses information outwith the article.

Prompt changes should be regression tested!

  • Get a real enquiry test case
  • Better test cases for people

As suggested by Juan Coquet some more improvements to testing should be:

  • ensure tests use redis docker container with localhost (instead of reading from env)
  • tests should spin up and down redis docker container as required

the code to be updated lives in compare_dres.py. i'm gonna approve this pr and feel free to merge, but please open a new pr to address this

item.title: [ERLLM-133] Refactor Vectorstore code (xi_milvus, le_milvus, etc) + integration testing
item.description:
There is currently a lot of duplication of critical code that defines how Milvus collections are created, with no single source of truth. This should all be consolidated into a central configuration.

Integration testing notes:

  • Ensure to include integration tests for unified Milvus insertion logic after refactoring (VectorstoreInterface.insert)
  • Mock the embedding calls. If one embedding call raises BadRequestError, it should be retried exactly once (see https://digital-insight.atlassian.net/browse/ERLLM-127 )
    • if it fails again, this should be logged and the chunk should be omitted (throwing out the chunk)
    • if the embedding call raises any other error, this should be logged and the error should be raised (throwing out the whole report)

Implementation notes:

  • ensure no Milvus dependency constructs leak (including exceptions)
    • test_xi_report_generation.py is currently catching MilvusException, it should catch a proper encapsulated error instead which does not make assumptions of the underlying database (Milvus, Chroma, …)
item.summary: Refactor Vectorstore code (xi_milvus, le_milvus, etc) + integration testing

item.title: [ERLLM-131] er-workflow-orchestrator bump er-contracts for ORG spike changes
item.description:
Jonah has been looking at SPIKES for organisation fingerprint services. After some investigation, it was decided that the services:

er-fingerprint-matcher
er-fingerprint-generator

needed to be aware of the type of DREs that they were being sent. Jonah then updated the contracts for the required types https://github.com/Digital-Insight-Technologies-Ltd/er-contracts/compare/v1.0.0-prerelease.143...v1.0.0-prerelease.144

Now, a number of things need to happen:

  1. Need to update the new repos to use the new version of er-contracts.
  2. Need to update er-workflow-orchestrator with new er-contracts to support the new contracts.
  3. Anything else??
item.summary: er-workflow-orchestrator bump er-contracts for ORG spike changes

item.title: [ERLLM-130] Migrate to using the safer safe_embed_texts method wherever possible
item.description: The safe_embed_texts method has added benefits such as automatic retrying over embedding_client.generate_embeddings, which is currently used
item.summary: Migrate to using the safer safe_embed_texts method wherever possible

item.title: [ERLLM-129] AKA extractor organisation AKA bracket handling
item.description:
It appears quite common for organisation AKAs to be found inside brackets. For instance

London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG)

Our current approach does not extract these. This should be a small amount of work.

Approaches might include:

Check if a target name appears in brackets anywhere in the document -> not so robust
Check if a ( immediately follows any target name in the document -> better, but may substantially increase cost

This has not been included in the ORG SPIKE as I want to discuss with Joseph, as I worry it could greatly increase the cost of the service as we might make far more calls.
item.summary: AKA extractor organisation AKA bracket handling

item.title: [ERLLM-128] AKA extractor inconsistent quotation extraction
item.description:
> Sophie Germain used the pseudonym "Monsieur LeBlanc" to correspond with famous mathematicians of

Was marked as skipped due to JSON parsing failing. I do not see it failing due to JSON parsing; instead it fails due to sometimes the naming coming out being wrapped in ““ and sometimes getting just the name.

We should decide which we prefer (or if we even care about quotations around AKAs) and make the relevant changes.

We could:

  • post process
  • Prompt GPT better

item.title: [ERLLM-127] XI BadRequest Error - Crashing Reports?
item.description: https://www.notion.so/xapien/Xapien-Insights-Dev-Stability-Issue-3rd-4th-December-1521edcf1daa80eaa7a0ebe7bc78f662

status.description: This status is managed internally by Jira

comments.comment:
Unfortunately, was not able to reproduce this on my machine. Ran on my machine fine (CLI) when using the same offending enquiry id.

Output of python3 cli.py insight_report with https://portal.devel.app.xapien.com/report/9db0e708-51a4-4b63-8342-ed460eeefac4 :

Juan similarly was unable to reproduce

output-nocache.txt

CLI output attached
https://www.notion.so/xapien/Bad-Request-Issue-1531edcf1daa806c810ae175ffe4edb8#1531edcf1daa801d8541fbd6541fb5dd
Error message found in logs resulting reports not generating due to this xi issue, so this was prioritised over the coref service.
Note for testing - Insure that the content for this Bad request is actually not importantby checking the elastic.

NOTE: Unittesting has been implemented for the more complex aspects safe_embed_texts and make_milvus_insertion_batches. Integration testing (test the insert function) has not been done as this work will need to be redone after refactoring. Instead therefore updated the requirements of ERLMM-133 (which tracks the refactoring) with the need to also perform integration testing.

Wrt BadRequestError – the changes to the insert function addressing this is minor and simple and so it was deemed acceptable to defer proper testing to a later stage due to the importance of adding logging asap.

item.title: [ERLLM-117] Bug template
item.description:
FROM SUPPORT
related tickets :
https://portal.support.xapien.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/3/SUP-524

Observed Behaviour: Describe what is currently happening, highlighting the issue in appropriate detail so developers can easily understand the problem.

Xi legal Sextion for PolyPeptide does not mention a patent lawsuit that is mentioned in the XI timeline section.

This is due to the paywalled bloomberg article which is the only article mentioning the lawsuit’s total text being less than the minumum chunk size and therefore not getting ingested into Milvus.
(However even if we reduce the chunk size in testing we still fail to recall the article unless specifcally asking about Firmagon Drug ERLLM-116 (the drug that the lawsuit was about)

  • How to replicate: Run XI locally on the Polypeptide report

Expected Behaviour/Acceptance criteria: Clearly outline what the expected behaviour should be.

item.title: [ERLLM-116] Xi Retrival Errors
item.description:
FROM SUPPORT
related tickets :
https://portal.support.xapien.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/3/SUP-637
https://portal.support.xapien.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/3/SUP-524

Observed Behaviour: Describe what is currently happening, highlighting the issue in appropriate detail so developers can easily understand the problem.

Report on King Abdulaziz University missing links to terrorism when asked even though this is the University where Bin Laden was radicalised and there are plenty of articles related. Through testing unless asking specifically about the university’s relation to bin laden we do not see relevant chunks being retrieved from the vector data store.

Report on Polypeptide Xi Legal prompt is missing infomation on a patent lawsuit Over Firmagon Drug that is in the timeline section. In this case it is caused in 2 parts the only article that mentions the lawsuit is a paywalled page and dropped from chunking and ingest as it is too small (ERLLM-117). However when the min chunk size is reduced we still fail to retrive this article when asking about lawsuits.

  • How to replicate: Steps required to replicate and which environment and product this relates to.
  • Evidence: Attach Loom (preferred) or screenshot showing how to replicate the issue.

Expected Behaviour/Acceptance criteria: Clearly outline what the expected behaviour should be.

King Abdulaziz University - On asking about terrorism links the answer should mention Bin Laden
Polypeptide - In the Legal Proceedings subsection we should mention the lawsuit over Firmagon Drug.

King Abdulaziz University example context and answers
caaf094d-9452-4605-978b-0e37cad55c20.json ccd2032a-e445-4d46-8d47-1e7276b70fb2(1).json f9ed1227-5df5-460f-b4e5-b7905c0b4e2b.json 25061a9a-1ed3-47b3-b04c-56fa910e0a6d.json

item.title: [ERLLM-115] XI failing to generate significantly more for LE reports
item.description:
Observed Behaviour: There is a significantly higher rate of XI failing to generate for LE reports in Devel. This is leading to entire report failures as now the full report has a dependency on XI.

  • How to replicate: Run several reports in Devel and see that XI fails with supprisingly high frequency
  • Evidence_:
    https://portal.devel.app.xapien.com/report/d07691b9-8a55-4839-97a6-7a40169decc9
    https://portal.devel.app.xapien.com/report/61be9748-af1b-45d3-b6cf-4db55be54ab7
    https://portal.devel.app.xapien.com/report/63df7e3e-da1b-425a-a0a7-5ebdbe152e4b

Expected Behaviour/Acceptance criteria: XI should only fail at same rate as in di-demo
item.summary: XI failing to generate significantly more for LE reports

comments.comment: Might be related to other tickets… not sure. Worth an initial check in the logs

item.title: [ERLLM-107] er-dre-extractor Investigate inconsistent test results
item.description:
We have noticed that the outputs of er-dre-extractor vary greatly between runs.

This is with temperature set to zero.

We want to understand:

  1. Do we expect the amount of variation we are seeing in test results? Does this indicate a problem in the MLB?
  2. Are the test outputs which are very varied valid outputs? (For instance, maybe they are arguable cases)

It may make sense to also look more generally at consistency in the MLB if it is suspected to be an issue. Though, we suspect controlling this randomness may well be outwith our control (specifically referring to the result we get from GPT).

item.title: [ERLLM-106] use DET token type to improve head selection
item.summary: use DET token type to improve head selection

comments.comment:
I tried out the DET approach -

It did work, but I think a more general solution is to allow one of any other type of token in our “best case head selection” logic.

This lets us also capture things like numbers (e.g. King Richard IX). This logic is implemented in the head selection code.

All test cases now pass!

Only one concern remains - regarding heads which are too long that we do not want to remove (and there is no suitable alternative head).
Joseph Whiting I’d like to discuss this with you in more detail. I want to better understand what our criteria are for a good “detailed summary”
https://www.notion.so/xapien/SPIKE-Organisations-Acceptance-Testing-14c1edcf1daa806eac08ed4bb06165f2

item.title: [ERLLM-83] Acceptance testing coref service
item.description: https://www.notion.so/xapien/Coref-Service-Acceptance-Testing-14a1edcf1daa80c4b380ec3c5085845e

item.title: [ERLLM-80] Coref service massive document guards
item.description:
→ Add test case with a very long document

→ Investigate to understand if quality drops significantly if documents are too long

→ Experiment to see how we could handle this - should we just split the document into smaller chunks and process those?

→ What is the limit running on GPU? How will we pick the max doc length to accept?

comments.comment:
Very long document (an entire shakespeare play) gives: Text of length 5458199 exceeds maximum of 1000000. The parser and NER models require roughly 1GB of temporary memory per 100,000 characters in the input.

This suggests that for 1,000,000 characters we might need 10GB of memory (just for NER).
https://www.notion.so/xapien/Coref-Service-Long-Document-Handling-14a1edcf1daa80f195c6fdfa55b095a8

item.title: [ERLLM-78] additional head selection testing for Corefs
item.description: We would like to add more head selection testing to better understand how well our head selection is performing. This should be on real data.
item.summary: additional head selection testing for Corefs

item.title: [ERLLM-77] DEFUNCT: head selection for XI Corefs
item.description:
We suspect that the current coref head selection code will be un-sufficient. The importance of head selection is twofold:

  1. The head must be interpretable, so that the GPT model can understand the chunks (the original goal of corefs)
  2. The head should look good for the user - we don’t want to present chunks on screen with chunks that don’t look right. This would represent a degradation in quality from the Fluenci solution.

To tackle this, we have a number of approaches:

  1. Something GPT based. This is my (Jonah's) favourite approach. This was Juan’s idea, and in my testing it looks like GPT should be very good at head selection. The disadvantage of this is the cost. So perhaps some initial criteria to select when we make a GPT call for head selection. For instance, if too high a % of a mention’s words are not proper nouns.
  2. Something hacky. Like I had tried with the reselection mentions, we could try logic based on number of proper nouns or entities. The problem with this is that many of the coref clusters we get aren’t necessarily about things that are identified as entities. For instance ‘the meeting ran by Jonah Ramponi’. I haven’t been able to a way (other than GPT) of cleaning this one up - since entity / proper noun approaches would likely just leave us with ‘Jonah Ramponi’.
  1. This actually isn’t a problem. I think the final approach is to hope that in cases where the output head was not good enough, there was a better head to select. Thus, the third approach would be to look at picking a better head from the candidates (if we identify that there is actually a problem here)
item.summary: DEFUNCT: head selection for XI Corefs

comments.comment: Closing, because was already covered by ERLLM-13 Head selection code

item.title: [ERLLM-76] BIN New corefs in ER XI
item.description:
Motivation: see design doc - we want to integrate corefs into XI under ER so that the accuracy of XI will be high AND we will be able to retire Fluenci (eventually)

Design doc

Acceptance criteria:

  • Corefs being generated on all FDocs
  • All being stored in document coref store
  • All being sent to XI
  • All being used by XI for interpolation in chunks as per existing XI
  • Testing on the outputs of XI has been performed to give us a level of confidence that the integration and the E2E quality is good

See also initial ticket for coref service for motivation https://digital-insight.atlassian.net/browse/ERLLM-3
item.summary: BIN New corefs in ER XI

item.title: [ERLLM-66] Improve alt text name detection - helpful for face contradiction
item.description:
The ER system uses alt texts to see when e.g. “John Smith” is the face in the image.

This understanding is important to be able to compare that face to the faces found for other John Smiths.

We currently use a very basic form of logic that checks if John Smith is in the alt text (with basic string normalisation). Something more elaborate might mean we can identify more face-name connections and thus get more use out of e.g. face contradictions in ER.

Initial logic used:

https://www.notion.so/xapien/Design-DRE-Mentioned-In-Alt-Text-Identification-93bf2bae3d194176b3753fb1cb4616af
item.summary: Improve alt text name detection - helpful for face contradiction

item.title: [ERLLM-60] More traces - instrumentation and add application level traces
item.summary: More traces - instrumentation and add application level traces

item.title: [ERLLM-56] Fingerprint generator statistical tests
item.description:
This will be for people fingerprints to begin with.

How might we write these statistical tests? We need to think about our criteria

  • How detailed should a fingerprint summary? (assert certain words appear in a given fingerprint summary)
  • How detailed should a fingerprint summary be? (assert certain words do not appear …)
  • How long should a fingerprint summary be? (check lengths of output summaries)

We could:

  • Build a quick set of 50 fingerprint summary test cases. (est 1.5 hr)
  • Ensure 95% of summaries meet each of our 3 criteria. i.e. 95% of summaries must be less than N characters, 95% of summaries must pass the ‘contains words’ and 95% of summaries must pass the ‘does not contain words’ tests.

item.title: [ERLLM-48] New corefs in production XI
item.description:
As a Xapien user reading the Xapien Insights section, I hate it when it hallucinates! It really undermines my trust in Xapien as a system that I can rely on for my job.

One of the main ways “hallucinations” are generated is when we use incorrect corefs in our RAG pipeline - coming from the Fluenci corefs.

We have a new FCoref approach and coref service which we think is much more accurate (from testing by Jonah Ramoni). We’re already implementing that for use in ER reports, but we’d like to benefit from the better accuracy in all reports.

Therefore the plan is to swap in the new corefs. We’ll route them to XI via https://digital-insight.atlassian.net/browse/ERIN-92. We’ll have to ensure that all the FDocs get sent for extraction and storage.

Coref related bugs here: https://digital-insight.atlassian.net/browse/ERLLM-40

A side benefit of this is that it decouples XI from Fluenci, helping us move towards retiring it and saving us money on our AWS bill

status.description: This status is managed internally by Jira Software

comments.comment: Needs design - Joseph Whiting

We’re holding this ticket for now - pending us coming up with a clear and low-risk approach
https://www.notion.so/xapien/Coref-XI-Integration-1491edcf1daa805498a8fc3ec362e86f?pvs=4#1491edcf1daa80dda0a0f8e2b543f985

item.title: [ERLLM-40] Incorrect CoRef assignment in XI
item.description:
https://portal.xapien.com/report/8b256a0d-f158-4e30-b45f-1481b37ea935

In the Links to Syria subsection of this report, information about Mr David Nott OBE’s work as a surgeon was assigned to Imran Yusuf. Both are mentioned in this article, https://www.fqms.org/category/events/page/2/, as speakers at the Celebrating Gaza Webinar. Imran Yusuf made a short film in the occupied territories and has not performed any surgeries.

d5a39f92-22ac-4463-9d23-ac85944cbe90.json

This is the input to GPT for the article.

comments.comment: Looks 100% like a Coref issue. Attached is output for FCoref. To produce this output, I ctrl+c’d the entire webpage (which I suspect is messier than what the model sees)
Added as a test case in the evaluator

item.title: [ERLLM-36] Show XI summaries on persona cards on enquiry summary page
item.description:
As an internal Xapien user I want to be able to distuinguish the personas on the enquiry summary page easily.

Having the executive summary from the XI report for each persona would allow that

Acceptance criteria:

  • For any persona with XI generated, the frontend shows the exec summary - truncated if need be for display reasons

This does not need to be production-grade UI as we don’t anticipate it being released to customers

item.title: [ERLLM-12] er-coref-service Build using FCoref
item.description:
Please let me know if this is not how to do this in Jira.

Here is a list of what I believe needs done:

→ Proper investigation into head selection. Try using NER models, try using GPT

→ Testing

→ Evaluation Framework. Tag X FDocs, which can be used for any future models to understand how well our coref model is performing.

→ Coref Filtering. This may come down to head selection. We may want to exclude corefs which are not valuable. For instance, we may want to only consider corefs which are people or organisations. This needs to be discussed.

→ Investigate speed-up of tokenization. This appears to be slow. FCoref can accept tokenized text as input, so our own implementation could be faster here.

→ Decide on model hosting. Sage maker? ec2 instance? What about evaluating how well this can process two enquiries at the same time? How might we handle that?

→ Make a list of known issues and problematic examples with FCoref.

→ Think about long document processing. Should we chunk? How should we chunk if so?

item.title: [ERLLM-11] er-dre-extraction cleanup
item.description: To bring the DRE extractor up to standard as per service report card

item.title: [ERLLM-10] er-face-extractor: fix pyright issues (devin)
item.description:
there are some unexpected typing issues being highlighted by pyright.

resolve these by updating the expected types. use the strictest type possible in cases where a choice is available — e.g. if an id parameter can be made into a str or a UUID, choose UUID.

item.title: [ERLLM-9] Observability - LLM usage costs
item.description:
See Doc: https://www.notion.so/xapien/LLM-Observability-13d1edcf1daa80ff9462fec884d33255

Currently, we only have brief napkin maths on the estimated costs associated with LLM api calls. This can be found here:

https://www.notion.so/xapien/LLM-Napkin-Maths-1351edcf1daa807b9414cfa134ff8338

We want to get observability of both throughput and cost for our services. We would like to ensure we have access to the following:

  • For a given enquiry, how much did we spend on our various LLM api calls?
  • For each service, how much do we typically spend on our LLM api calls?
  • What is our given throughput for each service?

To do this, we expect we will need to:

  • Track the number of input and output tokens for each prompt
  • Work with the MLB code to implement. We will pass a client reference in the MLB requests to ensure we can track back to both the enquiry being run, and the service being hit.
  • Ensure this is accessible via a dashboard, or some other observability interface. It should be easy to see for an enquiry (a) how much was spent and (b) where it was spent.
    • Should be quick and easy enough for Joseph Whiting to be able to access directly
    • Communicate how to use it with Joseph Whiting and Jonah Ramoni

comments.comment: blocked - waiting a conversation with James Buddrige of how to go about this
Ticket needs appropriately scoping

item.title: [ERLLM-8] SPIKE research how others resolve corefs
item.description: See https://www.notion.so/xapien/Coref-Model-Selection-1211edcf1daa80ccb3c3eb81dd91a0ea
item.summary: SPIKE research how others resolve corefs

comments.comment:
A wide review has been conducted. This had 3 stages. First, I tried to get a list of all approaches to the coref problem. I filtered these down with initial criteria (are their benchmark scores really poor, are they very old, etc). I then did deeper reviews on around 5-10 approaches. Finally, I took a few models and experimented with them locally. The model identified is FCoref, which aligns with the recommendation made by Hella.

I still do not find many people using Corefs in rag systems.
